HUDSON  “Gerosa” (1987) is on view in “Heavy Metal,” an exhibition of paintings by Joe Richards, through May 31 at Carrie Haddad Gallery, 622 Warren Street. For further information: 518-828-1915 or carriehaddadgallery.com.

PLEASANTVILLE  “Actress” will be shown on May 15 at 7:30 p.m. at the Jacob Burns Film Center, 364 Manville Road. A discussion with Brandy Burre, the documentary’s subject, will follow. Tickets are $10 and $15. For further information: 914-747-5555 or burnsfilmcenter.org.

PORT CHESTER  The comedian John Mulaney will perform on May 13 at 8 p.m. at the Capitol Theater, 149 Westchester Avenue. Tickets are $29 and $45. For further information: 914-937-4126 or thecapitoltheatre.com.

TARRYTOWN  “Beach Bloom” (2014), acrylic and oil pastel on canvas, is on view in “A Sense of Place,” an exhibition of paintings by Tjasa Owen, through May 17 at the Canfin Gallery, 39 Main Street. For further information: 914-332-4554 or canfingallery.com.

"This Is Our Youth": As brought to thin-skinned, full-blooded life by, from left, Michael Cera, Kieran Culkin and Tavi Gevinson, the three young characters in Anna D. Shapiro’s kinetically charged revival of this fine Kenneth Lonergan play are in a state of permanent free-fall. They exquisitely capture the sense of being lost, formless and on your own that descends with the end of adolescence (2:20). Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street, Manhattan, 212-239-6200, thisisouryouthbroadway.com. (Ben Brantley)

An artist's conception of Haramiyavia, which lived in Greenland more than 200 million years ago. The distance from the ear to the tip of nose was about one inch.

CT scans enabled paleontologists to reconstruct the jawbones and teeth of Haramiyavia, a rodentlike animal that lived in Greenland more than 200 million years ago. A new analysis indicates it was outside the family tree of mammals, though related.
The original analysis of Haramiyavia required years of preparation to expose the fossil.

A view of the Tyrrhenian Sea from the terraced garden surrounding the home of Nicola Del Roscio in Gaeta, Italy; in the dining room, a Twombly copy of a Picasso, done on top of one of his own works, above a Gothic chair found at a flea market in New York City.

The grand sitting room of the main house that dates from A.D. 1000, on the property of Nicola Del Roscio, Cy Twombly’s archivist and close companion, in Gaeta, Italy, with 18th-century frescoes thought to be by the artist Sebastiano Conca, a sofa from Andy Warhol’s home in Paris and terra-cotta tiles on the floor, handmade in a nearby village.

On a table in the grand sitting room, mementos including a poster for a Twombly exhibition in St. Petersburg, a Ross Bleckner painting, red coral and a leaf from the Seychelles, and a portrait of Del Roscio as a child by the artist Pasquale Di Fabio.

In the garden, rare and exotic plant species, including, from left, South African white bird of paradise, Palma de Pasobaya from the high Andes, Alexander palms from Australia and palo borracho from South America; Del Roscio in a small sitting room, with a painting of the Brazilian wilderness circa 1830.
An orange tree outside the cottage house that stores Twombly’s archives; a guest room in the main house, with an original 18th-century bed and doors.

A rarely used sitting room in the main house, where the furniture is covered in muslin sheets and an antique mirror keeps cold air from entering through the fireplace; the entryway of the house where Del Roscio now stays when he is in Gaeta, with a chair by Arne Jacobsen, 18th-century Neapolitan floor tiles and a poster for a Twombly show at Gagosian Gallery from 2008, framed with a vintage Del Roscio find.

The original image and three more visualizations after it was put through a neural network. The first layer is primarily detecting edges and color. The other layers begin recognizing more complex concepts like flowers, vases and lemons.

On the left is an image that was put through a neural network trained to classify objects in images — for example, to tell whether an image includes a vase or a lemon. On the right is a visualization of what one layer in the middle of the network detected at each position of the image. The neural network seems to be detecting vase-like patterns and lemon-like objects.

Neuron groups at two different layers of the network and the output classes. The lines show which neuron groups support or inhibit later groups or output classes. For example, a \“lemon\" classification is strongly supported by a yellow, lemon-y group.

Groups of neurons automatically learn to work together to represent concepts in an image. Five groups of neurons seem to correspond to flowers, the lip of the vase, the body of vase, the background, and lemons. A heat map shows where each neuron group fired on the image.
A \“vase\" classification is supported by the groups that represent flowers, the lip of the vase and the background.

The Green Gem community garden, on Glenmoore Avenue in East New York, is beloved by the neighborhood, but was shut down by a city program last month after inspectors found marijuana plants inside.

Intelligence officials said Mr. Batsh was targeted by Mossad, the Israeli spy agency. It believed Hamas had sent him to Malaysia to acquire technology and weaponry for use against Israel.

Mourners carried the body of Fadi al-Batsh, a technology expert for Hamas, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Wednesday. He was gunned down on Saturday in the Malaysian capital, where he had lived for seven years.
Masked members of the Qassam Brigades, Hamas’s armed wing, were stationed in front of a mourning tent for Mr. Batsh in the Jabaliya refugee camp in Gaza, where he grew up.
Enaas al-Batsh, right, is Mr. Batsh’s widow. “She comes from Gaza so she knows all about pain,” a neighbor said.

First graders at Church Lane Elementary Technology in Randallstown, Md., often use laptops in class. Their district, Baltimore County Public Schools, has embarked on one of the most ambitious technology makeovers in the United States.
A teacher helped second graders at Church Lane as they worked on their HP devices, which can convert from laptops into tablets. The district has committed more than $200 million for the laptops.
A student using the “Church Lane Hug” to carry her laptop securely.
Dallas Dance, the former superintendent of Baltimore County Public Schools, helping students with math on their HP laptops. Mr. Dance has appeared in videos for school vendors like HP.
Students at Church Lane and other Baltimore County schools are encouraged to study wherever suits them best — including in a hallway.
A student at Church Lane worked on his computer while children around him took a break.

The Baltimore County district has developed close relationships with, and won awards from, tech companies. Ryan Imbriale, a district administrator, was named an Education Visionary by Intel, which supplies the chips that power student laptops.
Students at Church Lane are also encouraged to read books offline.

Andy Byford, the chief executive of the Toronto Transit Commission, is scheduled to become president of New York City Transit next month. He said he would consider closing subway lines to more rapidly repair the city’s fraying system.

Mr. Byford said that making real progress in New York would require hard choices. “If we’re really serious we have to bite the bullet and to a certain extent inconvenience people while we get the work done,” he said, “but I will hold myself accountable to New Yorkers to say it will be worth the pain.”

Mr. Byford prepared for a television interview in Toronto, where he inherited a system plagued by problems similar to those in New York — chronic delays, aging infrastructure and constant track and signal problems.

The view from Mr. Byford’s office. Toronto’s system was named the 2017 transit system of the year by the American Public Transportation Association, which cited a reduction in delays and an increase in customer satisfaction.
A to-do list in Mr. Byford’s office. He has been

Mayer Herskovic was the only person to stand trial and be sentenced to prison for the 2013 gang attack on Taj Patterson in Brooklyn. The DNA found on Mr. Patterson’s sneaker was pivotal in the case against Mr. Herskovic. “I don’t believe that this is DNA,” Mr. Herskovic said of the evidence.

Evidence is examined at the DNA laboratory in the office of New York City’s chief medical examiner. Two DNA analysis methods — high-sensitivity testing and the Forensic Statistical Tool, or FST — have been discarded amid questions about the accuracy of their results.
Dr. Theresa A. Caragine, a forensic scientist, left, and Dr. Adele A. Mitchell, a geneticist with a specialty in statistics, invented FST.
From left, Andrew Feiter and Kamedra McNeil, forensic scientists, at a crime lab in Washington. Flaws in DNA methods temporarily shut down testing in some public crime labs, like this one.
Dr. Marina Stajic, the former director of the toxicology lab at the medical examiner’s office, testified that the city’s DNA lab should be transparent with its data.
Clinton Hughes, a lawyer at the Legal Aid Society, is part of a team that has challenged the admissibility of DNA results from the two disputed techniques.
Mr. Herskovic, at home in Brooklyn, is appealing his conviction. He said he agreed to give a DNA sample to the police because he expected it to show he was innocent. “I said, ‘Go ahead, take it!’”

Residents of the Kailahun district of Sierra Leone, near the Guinean border, at the Under 5 clinic waiting for passes to travel out of their Ebola quarantine areas. Health officials stationed here investigated the first confirmed cases of the outbreak in Sierra Leone.

Health workers in protective suits at the Doctors Without Borders treatment center in Kailahun, Sierra Leone. Wearing such suits in tropical heat makes it difficult to work with Ebola patients for long stretches.

A health worker at Foya-Borma Hospital in Foya, Liberia, testing the blood of a 40-year-old man suspected of having Ebola who was recently brought in by wheelbarrow. He did not contract Ebola and was released Monday.  Liberia's first known Ebola patient was brought to Foya-Borma in March.
A view from Nongoa, Guinea, where one can cross the Makona River into Sierra Leone by dugout canoe. It is one of several ways to easily move among the countries and Liberia.
Dr. Pierre Rollin, the top Ebola expert at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, believed in early May that the outbreak in West Africa seemed to be burning itself out.

Joseph S. Gbembo at a cemetery for Ebola victims in Foya, Liberia. His mother and three other relatives are buried there. The Gbembo lost 17 family members to Ebola in cases stretching from Sierra Leone to Liberia’s capital, Monrovia.

A list of the people suspected to have died of Ebola in and around the village of Meliandou, Guinea, during the current outbreak. The list, transcribed by a resident of Meliandou, begins with 1-year-old Emile Ouamouno, believed to be Patient Zero of the outbreak.

The village of Meliandou, Guinea, where a 1-year-old boy named Emile Ouamouno came down with symptoms consistent with Ebola and died in late December 2013. Emile is considered Patient Zero in the current outbreak across Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia.

Finda Nyuma, left, with her half sister Finda Focko at a village celebration in Sierra Leone. Ms. Nyuma died of Ebola around April 8; dying soon after were her husband, a grandson, several women who had prepared her body for burial and others exposed to them.
A villager on a path used to cross between Sierra Leone and Guinea. Relatively unfettered passage among those countries and Liberia has contributed to an Ebola outbreak.

The nurse Nafisatu S. Jabbie with a baby she had delivered at a community health center in Koindu, Sierra Leone. Two nurses at the clinic died caring for patients that had Ebola. A relative of Finda Nyuma was one of the clinic's first confirmed Ebola cases.
Finda Focko with her 2-year-old grandson, Kelvin, in Koindu, Sierra Leone. Ms. Focko had helped prepare the body of her half sister Finda  Nyuma for burial but did not contract Ebola.

Ebola-prevention advice at Guéckédou Hospital in Guinea, where some of the first suspected cases of the outbreak were treated. Dr. Kalissa N’fansoumane, the hospital director, said, “We thought it was a mysterious disease."
A man pointing to the grave of Finda Nyuma in Kpondu, Sierra Leone. The funeral of Ms. Nyuma, a traditional faith healer, led to other infections.

John Pye at Exponent’s test facility in Phoenix, where he oversaw months of experiments to determine whether air was intentionally removed from footballs used by the Patriots, or if the recorded air pressure levels could be explained by science.
Engineers at Exponent were tasked with studying the air pressure of footballs at its test complex in Phoenix in the aftermath of the N.F.L.’s Deflategate scandal.

Patriots quarterback Tom Brady is serving a four-game suspension after an inquiry commissioned by the N.F.L. concluded that it was “more probable than not” that Patriots employees were deliberately releasing air from footballs and that Brady knew about it.

Mr. Mitchell said he had trouble recruiting and retaining workers for his farm. “The big thing that’s on everybody’s mind is the labor shortage,” he said.

A farm run by Ross Mitchell in northern Scotland is struggling to find enough workers to pick fruit, a problem encountered by other employers since Britain voted last year to leave the European Union.
Mr. Mitchell’s farm is competing for an ever-shrinking number of workers as fewer workers from European Union countries are traveling to Britain.
Mr. Mitchell, above, said: “Guys who’ve worked five, six years with us started saying, ‘We’re not returning.’ It all came to a head in late summer and autumn.”
Without the labor needed to pick his fruit, including strawberries and blueberries, Mr. Mitchell has suffered heavy financial losses.

Tollbooths on the New Jersey side of the Holland Tunnel. Women who work as toll takers there and elsewhere complain of being subjected crude comments, obscene gestures and worse.

Varonica Ford, who works as a hairstylist and as a toll collector for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. She said that when a motorist makes an unsavory remark to her, she expresses her disapproval directly.

MENTAL HEALTH CLINIC Dominion Psychiatric Associates in Virginia Beach, where Richard Fee was treated by Dr. Waldo M. Ellison. After observing Richard and hearing his complaints about concentration, Dr. Ellison diagnosed attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and prescribed the stimulant Adderall.

Before his addiction, Richard Fee was a popular college class president and aspiring medical student. "You keep giving Adderall to my son, you're going to kill him," said Rick Fee, Richard's father, to one of his son's doctors.
COLLEGE YEARS Richard Fee was on the baseball team at Greensboro College.

QUESTIONNAIRE Richard Fee first received a diagnosis of A.D.H.D. in 2009, during a visit to a psychiatric clinic where he filled out a survey rating symptoms on a 0-to-3 scale. Having used stimulants in college to study, Richard appeared to have faked his responses in order to get a prescription.

PARENTS Kathy and Rick Fee with a photograph of Richard, who committed suicide in November 2011. They say they begged his doctors not to prescribe Adderall, an amphetamine to which he had become addicted. One of Richard’s doctors later said that his was a textbook case of the ways A.D.H.D. practices can fail patients.
SNAPSHOT Rick and Richard Fee at Yankee Stadium in November 2009. As Richard’s addiction worsened, he became more violent and eventually was asked to leave his parents’ home.
PSYCHIATRIST Dr. Charles Parker was one of the doctors who saw Richard Fee.

Some 4,000 drive-in theaters were operating in the heyday of the late 1950s. The number is down to 368, but some, including the Mission Tiki are going strong.

Julius Caesar A woman’s touch has not softened this manliest of Shakespeare’s tragedies. Phyllida Lloyd’s gripping, all-female,London-born production has a muscular strength and ferocity guaranteed to keep everyone in the theater in fight-or-flight mode. Sometimes it takes a woman to show what men are made of, a principle demonstrated by a crackling cast, led by Harriet Walter’s Brutus (2:05). St. Ann’s Warehouse, 29 Jay Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 254-8779, stannswarehouse.org. (Ben Brantley)

There are two identifying characteristics of a Shaniqwa Jarvis picture. The first is the perspective: the shots are usually taken from below. “I wanted to shoot cars just because,” she said of this photography from 2014. “But I was like, I want to shoot it in my way.”
Shaniqwa Jarvis
For the cover of her book, Ms. Jarvis shot this “self-portrait” of her niece, Madison Anderson, wearing Ms. Jarvis’s clothes and using her phone.
The other is the softness she brings out in her subjects, as in this portrait of Cardi B. “I have to make people trust me within five minutes,” she said. “That, to me, is the hardest part of my job.”
